awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Paleoclimate Reanalysis: A New View of Past Climates
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project aims to produce a Paleoclimate Reanalysis - a statistically robust gridded reconstruction of climate spanning the last 25,000 years - using a data assimilation technique widely used in the meteorological community in order to combine information from climate models and proxies to reconstruct gridded climate fields.  The Reanalysis will be used to test hypotheses regarding the response of the tropical Walker circulation and the major monsoon systems to changing climate background states and the origin of low-frequency (centennial to millennial-scale) variability in the Earth's climate system. The specific goal is to test hypotheses regarding the behavior of the tropical climate system under cold and warm climates and to document and identify the dynamical origin of centennial-to millennial-scale climate variability.

The Paleoclimate Reanalysis will be available to the wider science community and could provide a community benchmark to benefit research across multiple disciplines. This project will support a graduate student and postdoctoral candidate as well as involve substantial undergraduate participation in the form of data collection and analysis.  This project also support a new partnership with the Girl Power program to develop science education and outreach opportunities for middle school girls in a Tucson public school.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to reconstruct Earth's climate for the past 20,000 years by blending information from indirect ("proxy") records, and climate model simulations. Proxy records were gathered from previously published studies of geochemical markers taken from samples in ocean sediment records. Climate model simulations were also gathered from previously published studies that simulated the climate during the past 20,000 years. The link between the proxies and the climate models is provided by "proxy system models," which predict the proxy values from the climate model simulations. We developed a blending strategy for this information using data assimilation, a technique used to combine weather observations and models for weather forecasting. Using our adapted version of this technique, we reconstructed the average climate of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM; about 20,000 years ago), and also the time varying climate from the LGM to present at 200-year resolution.

We then used these climate reconstructions to study two fundamental problems in climate science: climate sensitivity, and the variability of the tropical climate. Climate sensitivity provides an assessment of how much the Earth warms for a doubling of carbon dioxide, including all "feedbacks" and changes that occur in the climate to adjust the heat content. It is an essential tool for understanding anticipated global warming, and has been somewhat uncertain with a range of values from different approaches. We use the LGM as a natural experiment to estimate climate sensitivity, since carbon dioxide values approximately doubled from the LGM to the modern climate. Our results yield a estimate of 3.4 degrees Celcius, which is larger than previous climate sensitivity estimates for the LGM, but consistent with estimates derived from climate model simulations. For tropical variability, we studied how the Walker circulation strength varied from the LGM to present, which reflects the climate of the tropical Pacific in the region of the El Nino phenomenon. Our preliminary results suggest that the Walker circulation has steadily weakened from its intensity during the LGM to its present value.
